text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

I'm the son of two
Nigerian immigrants.

And from an early
age, my family and I

conducted medical
mission trips back home,
as a way to give back.

I experienced a great
deal of human suffering.

We saw individuals without
proper sanitary equipment.
We saw medical supply shortages.

We saw significant constraints
in human capital because

of the brain drain that's
often prevalent in West
African countries.

And as a result, you just have
a very, very sick population.

And because of the aggregate
of all these experiences,

if you were to ask me what my
purpose in life was back then,
I would easily say physician.

I wanted to help less
fortunate people.

Today, nothing has
changed besides my path.

Pursuing a dual degree has been
transformational in broadening

my scope of the impact I
intend to make as an emerging
physician leader.

To be completely honest,
I'm not entirely sure

what my purpose is or
what my impact will be.
But I have a few hopes.

One, I hope to be one of many
leaders proving how people

interface with the
health care system,

specifically
marginalized communities,

those on the fringe of society
that, for historical reasons,

may not feel comfortable
seeking care.

I hope to make
life-saving medicines more
affordable for more people.

And above all, I hope to
promote health equity.
